title: Aiding narrative generation in collaborative data utilization by humans and AI agents
abstract: Abstract Narrative generation is growing in importance for data utilization, particularly in the context of co-creation with artificial intelligence (AI) agents. Narratives can, for example, bridge theoretical objects with social understanding and promote human actions. Furthermore, clarifying the narrative generation mechanism is essential for constructing effective relationships between humans and AI agents. However, the narrative generation mechanism in data utilization processes has not been fully elucidated. In this study, we developed a framework called the hierarchical narrative representation (HieNaR) to systematize the structure of narrative generation in data utilization processes. HieNaR comprises twelve levels, ranging from the set of texts down to the particle level (e.g., text, sentence, word, character, and stroke), allowing for a comprehensive analysis of narrative structures. We evaluated the usefulness of HieNaR through case studies, examining both individual user experiences and collaborative work between humans and an AI agent. The results demonstrated that the data utilization process interprets data by inquiring whether it satisfies higher-level expectations. In collaboration, AI agents can be understood as co-creative partners in data utilization, possessing their own worldviews. Through these findings, this study not only elucidates the mechanism of narrative generation in data utilization processes but also provides a foundation for improving human–AI collaboration.

Abstract
Narrative generation is growing in importance for data utilization, particularly in the context of co-creation with artificial 
intelligence (AI) agents. Narratives can, for example, bridge theoretical objects with social understanding and promote 
human actions. Furthermore, clarifying the narrative generation mechanism is essential for constructing effective relation-
ships between humans and AI agents. However, the narrative generation mechanism in data utilization processes has not 
been fully elucidated. In this study, we developed a framework called the hierarchical narrative representation (HieNaR) to 
systematize the structure of narrative generation in data utilization processes. HieNaR comprises twelve levels, ranging from 
the set of texts down to the particle level (e.g., text, sentence, word, character, and stroke), allowing for a comprehensive 
analysis of narrative structures. We evaluated the usefulness of HieNaR through case studies, examining both individual 
user experiences and collaborative work between humans and an AI agent. The results demonstrated that the data utiliza-
tion process interprets data by inquiring whether it satisfies higher-level expectations. In collaboration, AI agents can be 
understood as co-creative partners in data utilization, possessing their own worldviews. Through these findings, this study 
not only elucidates the mechanism of narrative generation in data utilization processes but also provides a foundation for 
improving human–AI collaboration.

1 Introduction
1.1  Background
This paper proposes a perspective that views the relation-
ship between humans and artificial intelligence (AI) agents 
as a process of data co-utilization. We argue that data use 
involves generating narratives from this joint utilization 
and elucidate the mechanism of narrative generation. This 
understanding can, in turn, foster more effective relation-
ships between humans and AI agents.
In recent years, narratives have been increasingly utilized 
as powerful tools for influencing individuals and societies. 
The effectiveness of storytelling has been summarized in 
that it can move and persuade people and produce results 
[Pierosara (2022)]. One of the reasons for the effectiveness 
is that an excellent competitive strategy demands a narrative 
story that shows images moving toward a goal as a whole 
composed of elements interacting with each other ([Kusu -
noki (2010)] p. v). Further more, narratives have demon-
strated the reciprocal relationship between theoretical enti-
ties and cultures [Heelan (1998), Ginev (2020), Sartori and 
Theodorou (2022 )]. Additionally, it has been argued that 
storytelling can effectively address both certain and uncer -
tain aspects simultaneously [Rasmussen (2005)].
A set of related terms used in this context includes nar -
rative, story, scenario, and storytelling. We use the term 
narrative rather than story  when focusing not only on the 
meaning of the whole composed of elements but also on the 
understanding of the elements or the whole, such as recog-
nizing a pattern from the elements [Cambridge University 
Press & Assessment (2022)]. Thus, narrative generation is 
the construction of a whole that is or will be composed of 
elements based on some understanding. When we focus on 
“possible actions or events in the future” [Cambridge Uni-
versity Press & Assessment (2023)], we refer to them as

scenarios. Finally, storytelling signifies the act of conveying

Data utilization involves the extraction of knowledge 
[Fayyad et al. (1996)], chances [Ohsawa (2002)], and their 
patterns [Ohsawa et al. (2021)] through a process. Here, the 
term data utilization is not limited to the analysis phase but 
encompasses the entire process of dealing with data, includ-
ing the synthesis of meanings. This extraction has been 
becoming increasingly focused on actionable outcomes, 
necessitating a deeper understanding of abstract patterns. 
In this context, we position the generation of narratives as a 
vital extension of these data utilization trends.
The role of AI in this narrative generation process is cru-
cial. Many AI systems use data as a knowledge base and 
source for model creation. As highlighted by [Jordan and 
Mitchell (2015)], advancements in machine learning—
driven by the sheer size of current data, low-cost computa-
tion, new algorithms, and related theory—have significantly 
enhanced this capability. A recent notable example is Large 
Language Models (LLMs). By integrating such AI agents, 
the extraction of knowledge, chances, patterns, and narra-
tives becomes more scalable and impactful. Furthermore, 
addressing the risks associated with AI agents, such as 
damaging human autonomy and turning the data utilization 
process into a black box, is imperative in this framework. 
Understanding the interplay between AI agents and data is 
crucial for mitigating these risks and ensuring the generation 
of desirable outcomes.
In conclusion, extracting narratives from data is key to 
fostering more effective relationships between humans and 
AI agents. This paper elucidates how this process can be 
realized and highlights the essential roles that both AI agents 
and humans play in this context.
1.2  Our approach
Although the aforementioned narrative extraction from data 
using AIs is significant, its mechanism has not been straight-
forwardly elucidated. If we can find a way to intentionally 
guide the narrative generation process, it will be valuable 
for constructing better relationships between humans and 
AI agents during data co-utilization. Therefore, we define 
the research problem of narrative generation for socially 
valuable actions in the context of data utilization as follows:
Problem Definition: Generate a narrative representing the 
actions and events in the causalities from/to the elements 
described below:
Element 1: Requirements (social demands in real life of 
human(s)) that correspond to a higher level of understanding 
of the data to be analyzed.
Element 2: Technical elements that correspond to raw 
materials such as the data to be analyzed and algorithms.
Element 3: Multilevel goals and solutions (goals, sub-
goals, and methods to achieve them) that make the above 
requirements easier to fulfill.
To address these issues, we propose hierarchical nar -
rative representation (HieNaR) as a framework. HieNaR 
has twelve levels: set of texts, text, subtext, sentence, sub-
sentence, word, subword, character, subcharacter, stroke, 
substroke, and particle levels.
Consequently, we define the three states of HieNaR: 
raw, descriptive, and patterned states. In the raw state, 
raw materials are represented. This state corresponds to 
both linguistic and numerical data representation when 
dealing with raw materials. Here, the linguistic case deals 
with data described in natural language. A typical exam-
ple is networked graph-type visualization with words as 
nodes. The numerical case  deals with numerical data, 
and typical examples include visualization using scatter 
plots, line charts, and histograms. In the descriptive state, 
the descriptive explanation of raw materials is presented. 
This state is particularly important in the numerical case 
because numerical data initially has little descriptive infor -
mation in its representation. In the patterned state, a pat-
tern that can be articulated from the raw or descriptive 
materials is represented.
An overview of HieNaR is shown in Fig. 1. In Fig. 1, we 
describe HieNaR levels vertically. Then, we describe the 
three states horizontally. The raw materials of the represen-
tation are shown on the left. In the center, we provide a 
descriptive explanation of the raw materials. On the right, 
we present the patterns. In this context, the word level cor -
responds to the granularity of the smallest independent 
meaningful unit in the narrative structure. Therefore, this 
case introduces a visualization of six levels out of the twelve 
levels in HieNaR, from the word level upwards.
In Fig. 1, the requirements (Element 1) of data utilization 
correspond to the upper-right levels, i.e., the sentence, text, 
and set of texts levels at which we aim to discover knowl-
edge, chances, or their patterns from data. The technical 
element (Element 2) corresponds to the lower-left side of 
Fig. 1. Here, we introduce a level that is explicitly expressed 
in the data utilization process, which is called the expressed 
level. For example, the expressed level of the scattered plot 
in Fig.  1 is the word level. Another example is a network 
graph whose granularity of the nodes corresponds to a key 
phrase and has the subsentence level as the expressed level. 
Then, multilevel goals (Element 3) corresponding to lev -
els and states are shown in the lower-left and upper-right 
representations.
Ideally, data utilization is achieved by working backward 
from the upper right to lower left. However, actual data uti-
lization is subject to trial and error. Therefore, the process is 
expected to be a cyclical back-and-forth movement between 
these upper-right and lower-left representations. To present

1.4  Related work
Narrative generation in data utilization is a complex pro-
cess. Despite its significance, the mechanisms underlying 
this process have not been fully elucidated. Our research 
addresses this gap by proposing a framework that eluci-
dates the connections between abstract concepts, including 
worldviews, and raw materials such as concrete data. This 
approach enhances the explicability of data utilization, lead-
ing to more strategically operable data utilization processes. 
An example of such a worldview is the expression of social 
values within narratives. Furthermore, our work seeks to 
delineate the roles and mutual influences of humans and 
AI agents in narrative generation, contributing to a better 
understanding and improvement of autonomy in human–AI 
collaboration.
1.4.1  Social values and social good
When narratives are generated with the intention of real-
izing social good, HieNaR effectively supports this process 
by visualizing the structure of scenarios that incorporate 
social values. Although social value and social good are 
related concepts, they are distinct. Social value refers to 
what is articulated within an entire system at the scale of 
a whole society, which can vary across contexts and can be 
expressed without necessarily determining its moral worth 
[Sekiguchi and Hori (2020), Sekiguchi (2022)]. This use 
draws inspiration from linguistic perspectives, where value  
is determined by differential relationships within a system, 
rather than inherent worth or moral judgments [Saussure 
(1959)]. Additionally, in relation to technology and society, 
[Poel (2020)] suggested that a social value can be positive 
or negative and depends on social, cultural, and historical 
phenomena as well as technological and personal contexts, 
and it evolves from time to time.
Then, research presented in [Floridi et al. (2020)] argued 
that social good is that which has a positive or nonnega-
tive impact on human life, the natural world, society, and/
or the environment. And they noted that what constitutes a 
socially good outcome is likely to be subject to disagreement 
and contention. Then, to make AI socially beneficial (good), 
research presented in [Floridi and Cowls (2019)] emphasized 
the importance of ensuring human autonomy and ensuring 
that AI-related phenomena are explicable (intelligible and 
accountable), along with the principles of beneficence, non-
maleficence, and justice. Additionally, they argued that situ-
ating these ethical principle to concrete actions is crucial.
By hierarchically connecting abstract worldviews to 
concrete data, HieNaR enhances the explicability of data 
utilization in expressing social values for realizing social 
good. This framework facilitates more strategic operability 
by enabling us to construct narrative structures more clearly.
1.4.2  Scenario building and autonomy
There are various ways to approach narratives in relation to 
AI and society, such as building scenarios and investigating 
moral dimensions. First, narrative-based future scenarios 
have been investigated to assist individuals in grasping 
future probabilities and improving their capacity to respond 
to future events. For example, storytelling techniques were 
used for scenario building, where it is important to consider 
to whom the scenario is relevant, the multiple contexts flow-
ing behind the scenario of the story, and the facilitator’s 
role in externalizing these hidden anticipations [Rasmussen 
(2005)]. The design of collaborative interfaces was demon-
strated to facilitate co-creation and conflict reconciliation 
[Stock et al. (2009)].
Second, regarding the moral dimensions of narratives, 
specific subjects, such as the autonomy of AI and the trust 
of humans, have been addressed. For example, the difference 
between human autonomy and AI autonomy is essentially 
shown in the way stories are narrated, and it is argued that 
human narratives are open to the future, whereas AI narra-
tives are merely combinations based on past data [Pierosara 
(2022)]. Narratives and technologies reflect the social struc-
ture and provide insights into existing inequalities that can 
be automated through advanced algorithmic and AI meth-
ods [Sartori and Theodorou (2022)]. Therefore, these studies 
consider narratives to be a key to tackling problems, such 
as addressing stereotypes. Furthermore, a method that inte-
grates both aspects was introduced [Copeland and de Moor 
(2018)]. This work expanded a storytelling workshop tech-
nique, namely community digital storytelling, by integrat-
ing a concept known as the storytelling cycle of trust. This 
approach has broadened the scope of storytelling, amplified 
its influence, and enhanced its impact both within communi-
ties and broader society.
While these studies have made significant contributions 
to scenario building and narrative analysis, they have not 
fully addressed the specific mechanisms of narrative genera-
tion process in data utilization. Our work addresses this gap

by proposing a systematic framework that merges scenario-
building techniques with data utilization. This framework 
enhances explicability, thereby improving strategic operabil-
ity. Consequently, it fosters the preservation and advance-
ment of autonomy throughout the process.
1.4.3   Hermeneutic circle, fusion of horizons 
and theoretical objects
One significant concept in understanding text is the her -
meneutic circle. Research presented in [Laverty (2003)] 
describes this as an evolving process of interpretation that 
emerges from the iterative movement between individual 
parts and the whole, with each aspect of understanding influ-
encing the other. She also argues that because this cycle is 
evolving, interpreters need to understand their own position 
and trace their movement within it. Furthermore, in creativ-
ity support studies, this hermeneutic circle is considered cru-
cial for aiding people, such as designers, in creative activi-
ties [Nakakoji (2006)].
Another important concept in textual understanding is the 
fusion of horizons [Laverty (2003)]. Hans-Georg Gadamer 
presented the concept of horizon as “the range of vision 
that includes everything that can be seen from a particular 
vantage point” ([Gadamer (2004)] p. 301). He argued that 
understanding is fundamentally a historical event, achieved 
through the fusion of horizons in which one combines the 
text’s horizon, rooted in the past, with one’s own horizon, 
which is continually forming (ibid. pp. 299, 305, 398). We 
can apply this concept to describe the data utilization mecha-
nism. In our terminology regarding the three hierarchies, the 
horizon corresponds to the full range of the worldview level, 
while the vantage point corresponds to the standpoint within 
the hierarchy of personal concerns.
Regarding knowledge extraction from data, there is a 
longstanding question of how scientists interpret experimen-
tal data. One trend is the adoption of hermeneutics, which 
posits that scientists, including natural scientists, interpret 
data, or more broadly, the world, as if they were reading a 
text. This shift towards an interpretation-based approach is 
known as the hermeneutic turn [Noe (1998)]. For exam-
ple, Patrick A. Heelan, drawing on Heidegger’s philosophy, 
argued that theory shapes history and culture, which in turn 
shape the practice of theory [Heelan (1998)]. Additionally, 
he discussed the role of technology in the form of theory-
based technology, including obtained data, as readable tech-
nologies. Dimitri Ginev expanded on Heelan’s argument, 
contending that these readable technologies transform theo-
retical objects into visualized entities [Ginev (2020)].
Therefore, we can consider that understanding narratives 
in data utilization also emphasizes the important role of the 
fusion of worldviews―one’s own with those of others, 
including theory-based views such as those of AI agents. 
However, the fusion of horizons among the three elements 
(i.e., one’s own worldview, others’ worldviews, and theo-
retical views) has not been visually elucidated in a narrative 
structure in relation to the data utilization process. Our work 
endeavors to address this gap as part of our approach to the 
research problem.
1.4.4  Roles of humans and AI agents
Human–AI collaboration has emerged as a significant trend 
in AI research, proposing that the goal is to achieve superior 
performance through synergy rather than replacing humans 
with AI. This approach recognizes the unique strengths of 
both human and machine intelligence. A notable example 
is the concept of hybrid intelligence proposed by [Deller -
mann et al. (2019)], which is based on the understanding 
that human intelligence is flexible, creative, empathic, etc., 
whereas machine intelligence is speedy, large-scale, consist-
ent, etc.
Such collaboration is diligently implemented and 
explored in creative activity support studies, including the 
enhancement of human cognition that is crucial for consider-
ing the narrative generation process.
Koichi Hori demonstrated that an AI system can sup-
port new concept formation by interactively visualizing 
spatial arrangements of words, providing alternative views, 
and offering stimuli to its user [Hori (1994)]. It has been 
shown that such a creativity support process aligns with the 
interactive process modeled as a double helix [Ohsawa and 
Nara (2003)]. In this model, two intertwined spirals pro -
gress simultaneously: one represents the human’s process 
of having concerns and becoming aware of new chances 
through context-shifting cycles, while the other represents 
the computer’s process of data processing and visualization. 
Further research has emphasized the critical role of human-
driven requirements (i.e., feature concepts) in data utilization 
[Ohsawa et al. (2021)].
Recent AI models have shown significant advancements, 
yet they still face certain limitations. Luciano Floridi and 
Massimo Chiriatti noted that models like GPT-3 (i.e., third 
generation of the Generative Pre-trained Transformer) 
encounter challenges in mathematical, semantic, and ethi-
cal tasks [Floridi and Chiriatti (2020)]. However, they also 
suggested that these limitations do not preclude effective 
human–AI collaboration. Kumiyo Nakakoji’s categorization 
of creativity support tools into three distinct types—dumb-
bells, running shoes, and skis—provides a comprehensive 
framework for analyzing how AI can enhance human crea-
tive processes [Nakakoji (2006)]. Dumbbells represent tools 
that develop creative skills, running shoes symbolize those 
that enhance performance during creation, and skis embody 
technologies that enable novel creative experiences. This

analogy effectively illustrates the multifaceted ways AI tools 
can support creativity.
This study is also grounded in these assertions. Regard-
ing the roles of humans and AI agents in data utilization, 
humans are expected to bring concerns and requirements 
aligned with their worldviews and to manifest their own cre-
ativity which is open to the future in the process. In contrast, 
AI agents can provide stimuli based on speedy, comprehen-
sive, and consistent computations. Our research proposes 
a framework that explicitly delineates these roles and their 
mutual influences in the narrative generation process.
1.4.5  Narratives and hierarchical representation
Some studies on information technology containing data sci-
ence were based on narratology, which is the field of nar -
rative investigation. These studies focused on decomposing 
and composing stories to realize effective information access 
[Akaishi (2006), Akaishi et al. (2007)] and generating stories 
[Murai (2022)], and they succeeded in applying a hierarchi-
cal way of thinking to model narratives.
However, they did not explain the narrative generation 
mechanism in the data utilization process as their hierar -
chies were not generalized to explain the various cases of 
data utilization. Further, they used these narrative structures 
for internal processing in computers, and their users only 
obtained results without an explicit representation of hier -
archical structures.
In addition, various types of hierarchical representations 
exist. The hierarchical representation has been generally 
investigated in system [von Bertalanffy (1968), Kawamoto 
(1995)], linguistics [Halliday and Matthiessen (2004), Bur -
ton et al. (2012)] and design [Simon (1996), Sekiguchi and 
Hori (2020), Sekiguchi (2022)] studies. These studies tend 
to define different hierarchies, whose integration would be 
helpful in systematizing the narrative generation mechanism. 
We, therefore, rearrange these hierarchies to explain the nar-
rative generation mechanism in the data utilization process.
The rest of this paper is organized as follows: Sect.  2 
defines the HieNaR and discusses its characteristics; Sect. 3 
describes the case study settings; Sect.  4 presents the case 
study results; Sect. 5 discusses the implications, limitations, 
and our future work; Sect. 6 provides conclusions. The glos-
sary of the words defined in this paper is provided in Table 1.
2  Definition and characteristics of HieNaR
In this section, we define HieNaR. First, we define its levels. 
Next, we classify the contents to be described at each level 
by dividing them into three states: raw materials, descrip-
tions, and patterns.
2.1  Twelve levels in HieNaR
We define HieNaR levels corresponding to the granularity 
of representation elements. Consequently, we define the 
twelve HieNaR levels: set of texts, text, subtext, sentence, 
subsentence, word, subword, character, subcharacter, stroke, 
substroke, and particle levels. Although various defini-
tions of hierarchical representation exist, as introduced in 
Sect. 1.4.5, we rearrange them to straightforwardly express 
narrative structure, which can generally be applied to explain 
the data utilization process. Table  2 presents an overview 
of the HieNaR levels, their semantic correspondences, and 
linguistic examples.
The classifications of a set of texts, a text, and a sentence 
are clearly defined. Specifically, a text has boundaries as a 
coherent whole, while any group of texts corresponds to 
the set of texts level. Sentences are distinctly separated by 
periods. It’s also important to note that for words, subwords, 
characters, and subcharacters, linguistically established def-
initions generally exist, allowing for clear differentiation. 
Strokes have definite starting and ending points, making 
them easily distinguishable. Particles are determined by the 
physical phenomena arising from the tools used for expres-
sion, such as pens, printers, or displays. Examples of ele-
ments classified within these categories are also shown in 
Table 2.
To make HieNaR robust, we introduce buffer levels: sub-
text, subsentence, and substroke levels. These levels cor -
respond to various component lengths. For instance, the 
subtext level can include paragraphs, sections, and chap-
ters, while the subsentence level encompasses phrases and 
clauses. Substrokes, while not always clearly delineated 
within continuous strokes, are also a crucial granularity. For 
example, in calligraphy, substrokes such as stops, flicks, and 
sweeps are crucial elements that significantly influence the 
aesthetic of the written characters. These sub-granularity 
levels function as buffers when dealing with various text 
types and writing systems.
Here, the text level corresponds to the narrative structure; 
hence, we call it the narrative level. Each sentence corre -
sponds to a piece of knowledge as exemplified in [Fayyad 
et al. (1996)]; thus, we call the sentence level the knowl-
edge level. We call the set of texts level the worldview level 
because views common to a set of texts (narratives) cor -
respond to worldviews, which is the source of narrative 
generation.
Then, the word level can be considered as the standard 
for the granularity of the smallest independent meaningful 
unit. This allows us to establish that, even in quantitative 
cases, the granularity of components that possess a smallest 
independent meaning corresponds to the word level. There-
fore, in this paper, we focus on the word level and above.

2.2  Relationship between HieNaR and other 
hierarchies
When investigating the narrative generation process for 
expressing social values, we can consider two additional 
hierarchies alongside HieNaR: the hierarchical represen-
tation of artifacts and that of personal concerns. Dfrome 
offers an exemplar of these two hierarchies [Sekiguchi and 
Hori (2020), Sekiguchi (2022)]. Figure  2 illustrates the 
relationship between these three types of hierarchies. The 
hierarchical representation of artifacts in Dfrome comprises 
seven levels: ethics, interaction, system, subsystem, sub-
subsystem, parts, and material, as shown in the middle of 
Fig. 2. The ethics level corresponds to social impacts (i.e., 
social values). The interaction level pertains to impacts on 
humans, such as users, participants, and citizens. The sys-
tem and lower levels align with those addressed in systems 
engineering.
The other hierarchy in Dfrome addresses personal con-
cerns. This dimension describes personal reasons and effects 
of the designed artifacts on stakeholders, corresponding to 
motivations and incentives. Furthermore, these representa-
tions of personal reasons and effects are defined to have a 
hierarchical structure, such as higher and lower levels of 
reasons [Sekiguchi (2022)].
These two hierarchies of Dfrome are orthogonal to each 
other. Dfrome is based on this three-dimensional representa-
tion, as depicted at the bottom of Fig. 2, and adopts a simpli-
fied version using projected images of the representation, as 
shown in the middle of Fig. 2.
We can position this simplified version of Dfrome’s hier-
archies within each area of HieNaR, as shown at the top of 
Fig. 2. Notably, concepts in the hierarchical representation 
of artifacts can be expressed at any granularity and in any 
state in HieNaR, ranging from particles to sets of texts, 
and from raw materials to patterns. For example, a concept 
at the ethical level can be expressed as a single word like 
“less-energy,” one of whose patterns can be “sustainable”; 
or as a phrase such as “a society to use less-energy,” one of 
whose patterns can be “a sustainable society.” This flexibil-
ity also applies to personal concerns, where a motivation can 
be expressed as a phrase like “scientific curiosity,” one of 
whose patterns can be “desire”; or as a sentence such as “I 
aim to satisfy my scientific curiosity and become a scientist,” 
one of whose patterns can be “Achieving self-realization.”
Therefore, the choice of granularity and state in HieNaR 
can be made independently from the other two hierarchies, 
rendering these three axes orthogonal to one another.
2.3  Simplification of the three states in HieNaR
As described in Sects.  1.2 and 1.3, we further define the 
three states of HieNaR, namely, the raw state, the descriptive 
state, and the patterned state. Although the representation 
utilizing the whole levels to each state in Fig.  1 covers the 
full information concerning the narrative generation mecha-
nism in a step, it becomes too complex to handle with the 
addition of an axis of the shift of steps in the data utilization 
process. Therefore, we simplify the full version of HieNaR 
as one hierarchy, as shown in Fig. 3.
In this simplified version, each level is first dotted with 
the frame of the area that represents each level. Then, the 
HieNaR user is required to trace the frame of the level with 
a solid line, where the data are explicitly dealt with (rather 
than in one’s mind or inside a machine), i.e., as the expressed 
level defined in Sect. 1.2. The levels with a dotted line above 
the expressed level correspond to the descriptive and pat-
terned states (i.e., our understanding of the expressed data).

3  Case study settings
We tested the validity of HieNaR S3 (i.e., the twelve lev -
els, the three states, and the temporal axis) for solving 
the research problem defined in Sect.  1.2 by investigating 
whether it could explain three specific phenomena related 
to the narrative generation in data utilization.
The three phenomena we dealt with included the possibil-
ity of expressing the social value of AI at various levels of 
granularity in a narrative; the discrepancy between initially 
held expectations and actual findings in the analysis (i.e., the 
creation of conflicts with data), which triggers the next stage 
of creativity; the creation of new narratives in human–AI 
collaboration through interactions based on their respective 
worldviews.
Through these cases, we also updated HieNaR to meet the 
expectation of explaining the narrative generation mecha-
nism in the data utilization process. Herein, we report the 
final equilibrium states of HieNaR and the explanation of 
each case.
In other words, this study is based on self-applicability: 
the input data for HieNaR relates to the narrative generation 
in the data utilization process, and we aim to generate a nar-
rative to understand its mechanism. Therefore, we studied 
these representative cases in detail, considering their qualita-
tive aspects. A quantitative investigation of this process will 
be conducted in the future.
3.1  Overview of the selected cases
We investigated three cases in the case studies. The first case 
deals with finding a scenario leading to the ethics level using 
Dfrome [Sekiguchi and Hori (2020)]. This case is significant 
considering the relationship between AI and society because 
Dfrome deals with the ethical (i.e., socially valuable) design 
of AIs. In addition, Dfrome utilizes two types of hierarchies, 
i.e., the hierarchical representation of artifacts and the hier-
archical representation of personal concerns. Through the 
investigation of this case, we could concretely organize three 
types of hierarchies including HieNaR.
The second case depicts a trial-and-error case to generate 
a new understanding of the O-shaped curve, an advanced 
case of the V-shaped curve. The third case is a collaborative 
case conducted to realize the collaboration between humans 
and an AI agent in storytelling [Shakeri et al. (2021)]. The 
latter two cases correspond to the creative triggers of the 
conflict in HieNaR, and the third case corresponds to the 
collaboration between humans and an AI agent.

4.1  Case 1: finding a scenario to the ethics level 
using Dfrome
The first case is concerned with finding a scenario leading to 
the ethics level using Dfrome. Dfrome is a creativity support 
tool used to promote ethical design practice by field engi -
neers (e.g., ethical AI design) [Sekiguchi and Hori (2020)]. 
Here, the term ethical design denotes the design considering 
the social impacts of the designed artifacts.
When using Dfrome, a user can describe design ideas. A 
design idea is described in an item in the form of a sentence. 
For example, “Vehicle => fly in the sky” is to be described in 
an item using “ => ” to signify “be changed to” for a means, 
or “will change to” for an effect. The designer must connect 
the items with other arrow types, such as “ → ,” depending 
on the supposed causalities. For example, a causal arrow 
can be described from the above idea to another idea, such 
as “Vehicle => fly in the sky → Roads => be less congested.” 
Then, a scenario is defined as a path comprising items and 
arrows.

sion for dealing with personal reasons, as shown in (P) in

sons and effects on the designer due to space limitations.
In this case, the task was to find an ethical scenario for 
developing paragraph vectors [Le and Mikolov (2014)]. 
Here, the input data were considered as a tree comprising 
items and arrows positioned at the system and lower levels.

4.2  Case 2: Trial and error for a new understanding 
of the O‑shaped curve
The second case involves the demonstration of trial and error 
to generate a new understanding of the O-shaped curve. In 
the abovementioned case, the higher-level expectations did 
not change in the data utilization process. However, in actual 
data utilization, data analysts often experience a conflict 
between the expectation and what the data show. Through 
resolving this conflict, they develop a new understanding of 
the data. In this case, we dealt with an imaginary case that 
began with the expectation of obtaining a smiling curve.
The theme dealt with was the relationship between the 
trends of “Fuyu-fuku” written in Japanese Kanji (“win-
ter clothes” in English) and the temperature in Tokyo. 
We obtained the weekly trend data in Tokyo via Google 
Trends (https:// trends. google. co. jp/ trend s/? geo= JP) and 
the weekly temperature data via the Japan Meteorological 
Agency (JMA) website (https:// www. data. jma. go. jp/ gmd/
risk/obsdl/), which corresponded to the Tokyo observation 
point defined by the JMA. These data are downloadable in 
the comma-separated values file format. We obtained these 
data in October 2022. The sampling period was from Octo-
ber 15, 2017 to October 8, 2022.
To begin with, the analyst started by preparing the input 
data with the expectation that he/she could obtain a smirk 
curve of the relationship between winter clothes and tem-
perature as a concrete case of commodity trends against 
temperature as shown in Step 1 in Fig.  6. Here, the analyst 
anticipated that the curve would be skewed (i.e., the shape of 
the left half of the smiling curve) because the trends seemed 
to rise when the temperature decreases and did not seem to 
rise even if the temperature increases.
The analyst visualized the data using a scatter plot in 
Excel and identified a conflict between these expectations 
and the results of the visualization, as shown in Step 2 in 
Fig. 6. He/she had to find new knowledge to understand why 
the upper and lower sides of the smirk curve were separated 
at the knowledge (sentence) level. At the narrative (text) 
level in Step 3, the analyst also had to explain why the data 
collectively formed an O-shaped curve.
To answer these questions, the trial-and-error approach 
was adopted as shown in Step 4 in Fig. 6. The intermediate 
objective was to identify the data segments corresponding to 
the upper and lower parts of the curve. The Filter function in 
Excel was useful because it allows one to easily extract some 
parts of the data and instantly update the graph.
Although this process required trial and error (e.g., check-
ing various attributes to filter the data), little everyday or 
industrial knowledge was helpful in solving the problem. 
For example, we know that summer clothes go on sale before 
summer is over. Shortly thereafter, fall and winter clothes 
are on the store shelves. This indicated a time lag (or phase 
difference) between the rise in winter clothing trends and the 
actual fall in temperature. Thus, filtering the data by month 
worked well in this case. When the data were plotted on 
the graph for each month, they were visualized as a circle 
around each part of the O-shape.
In Step 5, the analyst finally divided the data by month 
to clearly show the new understanding obtained. Figure  7 
presents the actual graph. The number on each plot repre-
sents the corresponding month. At the knowledge level, the 
analyst could enhance and refine his/her understanding of 
how the upper, lower, left, and right sides of the O-shaped 
curve correspond to different aspects of the data, such as 
“the upper side corresponds to the growing trend to prepare 
in advance for cold weather,” “the lower side corresponds to 
a ceasing trend in advance,” etc. Then, the analyst obtained 
the understanding that the O-shaped smirk corresponds to 
the cycle for seasonal changes at the narrative level.
Thus, HieNaR S3 elucidated the trial-and-error process 
in data utilization for narrative generation as a process of 
reconciliation between different levels of understanding.

5  Discussion
The case studies concretely demonstrated that the three phe-
nomena can be clearly expressed by applying HieNaR S3, 
i.e., expressing social values in various levels of granularity, 
effects of creative conflict, and collaboration based on vari-
ous worldviews.
5.1  Expressing social values for social good
As demonstrated in Case 1, the HieNaR framework has 
proven valuable for explicitly assessing social values. 
To begin, this case illustrated how Dfrome could con-
nect technical elements to ethical considerations in AI 
development, thereby visualizing the path from technical 
design to the ethics level that corresponds to social values. 
A critical point to note was that Dfrome emphasized the

However, although Dfrome provided a space to express

As observed in Case 3, such visualization in HieNaR 
facilitated the generation of new narratives through col-
laboration. These findings suggest that, by systemat-

social values, collaborative efforts centered on narratives 
addressing these values are likely to foster both the crea-
tion and realization of social goods.
5.2  Relationship between the three types 
of hierarchies
The three hierarchies could be understood as orthogonal 
to one another using the case’s concrete materials. Specifi-
cally, the three axes provided the hierarchical representa-
tion of the narrative (HieNaR), the hierarchical representa-
tion of the artifacts, and the axis of the individual’s point 
of view.
In detail, as for the social values related to the relation-
ship between AI and society, the ethics level of Dfrome 
directly dealt with social values. Placing some ethical val-
ues from various options at the ethics level involved the 
effects of the choices in the personal view, such as profes-
sion, belief, passion, etc.
However, using Dfrome did not necessarily mean the 
ethics level was dealt with as described above. To express 
this at the ethics level, we confirmed an expectation to 
handle the ethics level at the higher levels in HieNaR. Hie-
NaR’s narrative and worldview levels directly described 
the pattern of such an intention as obtained in Case 1.
Furthermore, it is important to note that the expres-
sion in HieNaR could be determined independently of the 
expression in Dfrome, thus emphasizing that the three axes 
are orthogonal to each other.
5.3  Existence of creative conflicts
Cases 2 and 3 showed that the conflicts in HieNaR levels 
could potentially promote creative activity because the con-
flict was not necessarily negative as it might lead to a new 
understanding. The HieNaR’s visualization of the conflict as 
the relationship between the levels was helpful in systemati-
cally addressing the situation. Then, the conflict reconcili-
ation process corresponded to a type of fusion of horizons 
in hermeneutics, as discussed in Sect.  1.4.3. Notably, the 
results of representation, which correspond to the subjec-
tive text in the general hermeneutic process, dynamically 
changed in the data utilization process, especially in collabo-
rative work. HieNaR allowed us to understand this dynamic 
process in a visual manner.
Therefore, whether static or dynamic, HieNaR promotes 
creativity by visualizing conflicts between levels, fostering 
new insights in data utilization.
5.4  Rooted in the participant’s own worldview 
when collaborating to use data
In a collaboration-style data utilization, the levels higher 
than the expressed level corresponded to the latent con-
texts of participants (Fig. 8). Thus, we were able to directly 
express different interpretations one could have despite 
looking at the same data. This enables us to adopt a more 
structured approach by determining the appropriate level for 
integrating options. This determination serves as a basis for 
selecting different storylines and contents to realize alter -
native narratives, while acknowledging potential risks and 
vulnerabilities associated with these actions.
In addition, the three cases showed that the data, algo-
rithm, and tool described in Sect.  1.4.3 correspond to the 
theoretical entities at the expressed level. Especially in 
the collaborative case, the relationship between the theo-
retical entities, a user’s own worldview, and the other users’ 
worldviews could be visually organized as shown in Fig. 8. 
Additionally, using the three axes, we confirmed that the 
worldview can exist at the highest level in HieNaR. It is a 
representation generated by the intersection of patterns at 
the set of texts level that are expected to equilibrate to the 
artifact representation whose ideas are selected by the cor -
responding personal views.
Furthermore, when a user used an AI agent (LLM) in 
Case 3, the AI agent already had its own worldview set 
by OpenAI. A specific worldview was added as the initial 
prompts as “being a storyteller and realizing other partici-
pants telling stories themselves.” Therefore, the operation in 
which the user input prompts to the AI agent and obtained 
outputs meant that the AI agent generated a narrative that 
was consistent with not only the preceding storyline but also 
the and condition between the storyline, the worldview set

by OpenAI and the role of the storyteller set by the human 
participants via the initial prompts.
Therefore, for AI agents, since the two components that 
constitute the worldview (the one by the provider and the 
one by the initial prompt) do not change during the data 
utilization process, the worldview seems maintained as long 
as the expectation for the storyline does not change from the 
worldview level.
5.5  HieNaR and the hermeneutic circle
The process of deepening understanding through interac-
tions among various levels in HieNaR aligns with the herme-
neutic circle [Laverty (2003), Nakakoji (2006)]. Each level, 
from the word to the set of texts, is considered to possess 
its own social, cultural, and historical backgrounds. For 
instance, words have their historical roots, while texts have 
their historical contexts. The overall meaning of elements at 
each level is formed within the complex relationships woven 
by these levels.
The dynamic aspect of the interaction between levels cor-
responds to the hermeneutic circle. Changes at one level 
have the potential to update the backgrounds of other levels. 
This was exemplified in Cases 2 and 3, where the content 
at the expressed level created a conflict in the relationship 
between levels. As shown in these cases, this conflict neces-
sitated an update to the content of the narrative below the 
text level.
Moreover, each element at the subword level or below, 
not covered in this study, is also considered to possess its 
own unique social, cultural, and historical backgrounds. 
Considering these new backgrounds can open up possibili-
ties for novel interpretations, highlighting the importance of 
exploring these lower levels as well. The case for addressing 
such levels at and below the subword level will be discussed 
in a future study.
5.6  Practical implications
5.6.1  Improving the data utilization process
Then, we consider the practical implications. Using Hie-
NaR and applying the knowledge obtained in this paper, we 
can more clearly operationalize the data utilization process. 
Specifically, it is possible to visualize at what level conflicts 
need to be resolved in the data utilization or to visualize 
multiple contexts individually and design interrelationships 
between them. The results of a higher-quality analysis based 
on such a narrative can lead to actions.
Meanwhile, we can reasonably assume that many failed 
cases went unreported, particularly in academic papers. Hie-
NaR can explain the cause of failure as an inappropriate 
relationship between the levels. For example, when there 
is a conflict in HieNaR, the whole data or the algorithm 
can be changed. Such a failure is probably caused by the 
wrong tool selection. The tool used in the analysis must be 
selected because its algorithm is beneficial to realizing the 
expectation.
Another reason can be the lack of proper expectations 
at higher levels, as shown in the trial-and-error case in 
Sect. 4.2. To solve this incorrect relationship, the trial-and-
error step for constructing a new understanding is crucial. 
Knowledge is useful in reconciling the conflict.
The application of these insights derived from analyz-
ing these potentially problematic cases can enhance the 
data utilization process. By systematically identifying and 
addressing these failure modes, we can improve the ana-
lytical workflow, thereby increasing the efficiency of data-
driven projects.
5.6.2  Promoting further creative activity in the data 
utilization process
We can support creative activity by questioning what is 
undoubtedly set as the pre-supposition ([Wittgenstein et al. 
(1969)] pp. 44–44e, [Kobayashi and Funabiki (1995)] pp. 
17–26, [Sekiguchi and Hori (2021), Sekiguchi (2022)]). 
First, reconsidering from the highest level of HieNaR (i.e., 
worldview level) can lead to more creative data utilization. 
For example, group work such as workshops can stimu-
late creativity through collaborative conflicts and diverse 
worldviews. In addition, acting as a facilitator as described 
in the introduced case in Sect.  4.3 can make latent contexts 
explicit, enhancing this process.
Second, case studies revealed that tool specifications dic-
tate the expressed level of data utilization, which remains 
constant with the same tool. The HieNaR model allows users 
to visually identify and adjust their expressed level, encour-
aging the inclusion of higher-level insights that are often 
omitted during the result-saving phase, as shown in Case 2. 
Making these higher levels explicit aids in enhancing later 
understanding.
In the context of Nakakoji’s categorization of creativ -
ity support tools [Nakakoji (2006)], Case 3 demonstrated a 
ski-type creative process where AI facilitated novel collabo-
rative narrative generation. Furthermore, HieNaR oper -
ationalized this concept by providing a structured frame -
work to visualize this innovative mechanism, allowing us to 
refine human–AI collaborative creativity. Therefore, when 
we implement an AI promoting HieNaR practice, such a 
HieNaR-based AI will support its user in the ski-type man-
ner, too.
Additionally, this application of the ski concept to both 
the AI narrative facilitator and HieNaR’s analytical frame-
work showed how Nakakoji’s classification can be applied to 
LLM-based creativity support tools, enabling researchers to

systematically explore different patterns of human-AI inter-
action in narrative generation.
 The importance of freely varying granularity was once 
argued by Jerry R. Hobbs [Hobbs (1985)] but remained 
unresolved. This study has redefined this issue from the 
perspective of narrative generation in data utilization. One 
of our future tasks is to apply LLMs to this free switching 
of granularity in our creativity support tool for providing 
HieNaR S3.
5.6.3  Preserving people’s autonomy against LLMs
HieNaR’s visualization enhances explicability and strategic 
operability, including in collaborations with powerful AI 
agents such as recent LLMs. While AI agents co-creatively 
influence content, we can consider that users can exercise 
their subjectivity by intentionally engaging in the fusion of 
horizons [Laverty (2003), Gadamer (2004)] in a way that is 
open to the future [Pierosara (2022)]. HieNaR facilitates this 
by providing a visually structured framework that enables 
users to consciously integrate various worldviews among 
participants, including those of AI agents.
As demonstrated in Case 3, this fusion process becomes 
particularly evident when conflicts between different levels 
occur. Through explicit representation, HieNaR empowers 
users to adapt or maintain their own worldviews, which are 
visualized at the top level of the HieNaR framework should 
incorporate contents that are open to the future. Users can 
then accept, modify, or reject AI-generated content, such as 
changes in storylines at the subtext level. These contents can 
be positioned at various levels due to differences in granu-
larity, including the worldviews of AI agents. In this way, 
HieNaR offers insights into the strategic distribution of con-
tributions at various levels among participants, leading to a 
better balance of autonomy between humans and AI agents.
Moreover, HieNaR provides a temporal perspective that 
aids in understanding the dynamics of human–AI interac-
tion by tracing changes in users’ interpretation over time, 
the necessity of which is argued by [Laverty (2003)]. This 
applies to both individual narrative generation processes and 
long-term coexistence with AI in daily life. This awareness 
of evolving perspectives allows users to improve their inter-
actions with AI systems over time.
We can replace AI agents when new ones offer superior 
performance or when current agents’ worldviews misalign 
with our own worldviews and lives. This is especially impor-
tant because, as shown in Case 3, the worldviews implemented 
in AI agents do not necessarily change during each data uti-
lization process. Therefore, we must adhere to the policy of 
developing pluralistic AI agents, particularly LLMs that exert 
significant influence on people and society, to preserve human 
autonomy. It is crucial to have options for people to select 
AI agents whose embedded worldviews align with their own 
worldviews and lives.
These discussions introduce a new perspective on the 
moral dimensions of narratives, particularly in response to 
the challenges posed by recent LLMs. Implementing these 
support mechanisms represents a significant area for future 
investigation.
5.7  HieNaR’s limitations and future work
HieNaR is capable of addressing the logical consistency in 
part–whole relationships, including worldviews, as exempli-
fied by its ability to presuppose and realize the expression of 
social values within narratives, as shown in Case 1. However, 
it cannot independently make value judgments, such as deter-
mining what is good or bad. This point refers to the other 
principles introduced by [Floridi and Cowls (2019)] besides 
autonomy and explicability, i.e. beneficence, non-maleficence, 
and justice. To support the realization of social good, another 
system for value judgments is necessary, which remains a chal-
lenge for future research.
The network structure dealt with in HieNaR is limited to the 
internal structure of what is expressed. For example, HieNaR 
does not address factors such as the material on which the 
expression is made (e.g., paper, cloth, digital). At the particle 
level, which is the smallest unit in HieNaR, interactions with 
these materials would give rise to elements as substrokes, but 
currently, only one aspect—what is expressed—is addressed. 
In fact, delving into the discussion of materials opens up fur-
ther possibilities for cultural discourse. For instance, in cal-
ligraphy, the choice of materials significantly influences the 
worldview. Addressing these relationships with the world 
outside of HieNaR remains a future challenge.
Finally, there must be a gap between providing a framework 
and having it put into practice. To encourage more practical 
implementation, it is effective to create tools equipped with 
the vocabulary and grammar of the HieNaR framework. First, 
we plan to realize a tool that can provide HieNaR S3 with 
interactive user interfaces and algorithm options. Each algo-
rithm tends to define a pattern, and we must change algorithms 
corresponding to the expected pattern. Second, we plan to pro-
mote co-creative data utilization using a new tool to express 
and reconsider the presupposition at higher levels because the 
understandings at these levels differ among participants and 
are useful to recognize different perspectives. Finally, using 
this tool, we plan to aggregate various cases and conduct a 
quantitative analysis.

6  Conclusions
This study proposed HieNaR, a hierarchical framework 
that explains the narrative generation mechanism in the 
data utilization process. HieNaR can straightforwardly 
express narrative structure by rearranging the knowledge 
of fields dealing with narratives in a hierarchical man-
ner. Here, it is generalized to deal with various numeri-
cal and linguistic data utilization cases. The usefulness 
of the straightforward explanation of the narrative gen-
eration mechanism using HieNaR was demonstrated by 
performing three case studies to investigate qualitative 
characteristics.
A systematic understanding of the narrative generation 
mechanism in the data utilization process is significant 
because this understanding is necessary for promoting 
meaningful analyses and generating actions. It is also 
effective for realizing further creative activities. Further -
more, it can lead to the development of better relationships 
between contemporary data-driven AI systems and humans 
by visualizing the collaborative hermeneutic process.

Operational rules for consistent HieNaR use
We set six rules to make the HieNaR operation consist-
ent and useful. While the former ones are more essential 
in maintaining consistency, the latter ones are established 
due to their operational usefulness. Since the linguistic case 
makes the application of these rules clearer, we explain it 
based on Fig. 9.
Node of an un‑composed element
Except for the lowest level, all nodes are supposed to com-
prise two or more elements. However, we must consider a 
node with a single element to maintain consistency between 
levels. For example, nodes with a dashed line in Fig.  9 cor-
respond to such nodes. Typical examples include the words 
“it,” “is,” “comfortable,” and “around” at the subsentence 
level. The manipulation allows us to construct the sentence 
“it is comfortable around between 20 °C and 25 °C.” by 
combining six nodes at the subsentence level, that is, “it,”

and “. (period).”
Nonnecessity of patterning
In the patterned state, not all nodes are necessarily patterned. 
For example, the gray-painted nodes in the patterned state 
in Fig. 9 correspond to such nodes. Using this rule, nodes 
that are not easily patterned are allowed to remain in their 
raw states.
Word omission
HieNaR can omit particular words in representation. For 
example, actual analyses tend to omit stopwords that appear 
too often to analyze their meanings (e.g., “a,” “the,” “and,” 
“or,” “but,” “in,” “of,” etc.). The analyst abductively inter -
polates and/or extrapolates these words to construct nodes 
at a higher level.
Level skip
The levels we cannot pay significant attention to can be 
skipped when describing HieNaR. For example, the sub-
sentence level can be skipped if we think of sentences by 
seeing words.
Approximate the descriptive state to the raw state
When we deal with natural language data, some raw data can 
be considered as a type of descriptive data. If we simplify 
and consider the raw natural language data to be the same as 
descriptive data, we can omit one of them as shown in Fig. 9. 
Pattern for state or action
The patterns described in Fig.  9 involve a noun or a noun 
phrase. However, they can be described in various ways, 
such as clauses, sentences, and texts based on the condition 
that the lower-level pattern is a part, and the higher-level pat-
tern is a whole. The only rule to maintain is that the concept 
at the higher level contains the concept at the lower level.
